title.narrative: Tackling child labour in coffee supply chains in Vietnam

description.narrative: While coffee farming and productivity in Vietnam has had an impressive growth over the last 30 years to become the world’s 2nd largest producer and exporter of coffee after Brazil, the sector has its challenges. The International Centre for Tropical Agriculture reported that in 2015, 11.3% of the population in the Central Highlands was living under the national poverty line – 95% of Vietnam’s coffee is produced in the Central Highlands region. Assessments conducted by project partners and independent audits in recent years have detected child labour cases in coffee farms, particularly among families from ethnic minorities. Interviewees reported that children from ethnic minority families face a higher risk to drop out of school at an earlier age for multiple reasons, including marriage (especially in the case of girls), low household income, child labour and limited ability to speak Vietnamese.Having identified child labour cases in regions of the Central Highlands where the participating companies source coffee, the project partners have come together to tackle this issue.The project aims to work with 1,500 smallholder farmers from the provinces of Dak Lak and Gia Lai to monitor, remediate and prevent child labour. As a first step, a detailed research will increase the understanding of the specific local risk factors, root causes and power dimensions between the different actors in the coffee sector. The research will also focus on the gender aspects of child labour in coffee. This understanding will help project partners to develop a context-specific response in the best interests of children. The following phase will focus on improving the capacity of farmers to develop and maintain a risk-based system; increasing household income through improved farm management practices and support additional Income Generating Activities; working with key stakeholders on awareness raising campaigns in local languages; improving access to quality education; supporting the development of coffee specific guidelines to tackle child labour on farms; and sharing learnings with other sectors in Vietnam and with the coffee sector internationally.
